selected_quotes: Is there any dentist in Mars? Dentistry space exploration

citation.abstract: Current projected missions to Mars will require 18 to 24 months of exposure to microgravity conditions, which might have serious effects on human physiology, including that of the oral cavity. Very few studies have been published on the effect of microgravity on the oral cavity, although it has been reported that microgravity increases the prevalence of periodontitis, dental caries, bone loss and fracture in the jaw bone, pain and numbness in teeth and oral cavity tissue, salivary duct stones, and oral cancer. Aeronautic dentistry is a new field, so further study of the effects of microgravity are required. In this article, we review the role of aeronautic dentistry in space missions and offer our recommendations for the future growth of this field.
citation.title: The history and importance of aeronautic dentistry.

author.name: Sergio Uribe
author.description: Evidence Based Dentistry | PhD, MSc, DDS |  #PUQ | Skeptic | #Rstats | #Dentistry | #OralRadiology | Reinheitsgebot | Data science

blogs.title: “Proven plagiarism” extracts paper on keeping teeth healthy in outer space
blogs.summary: Aeronautic dentistry seems like a fairly unique field, but a review article about keeping teeth healthy in outer space has been retracted from the International Journal of Stomatology & Occlusion Medicine for not being quite unique enough. “

author.name: Retraction Watch
author.description: Tracking retractions as a window into the scientific process
